Comment: The only real historical precedent here is the election of 1800, where the contingent election went into round after round after round of voting while the parties went back and forth trying to negotiate until someone emerged a winner. This isn't the *best* precedent because since then we've changed a lot about how we apportion electors, but the overall bones of a contingent election having multiple rounds would still hold.  Eventually, someone would break. Eventually, the parties would negotiate and compromise until someone wins. Either that, or our system would enter a constitutional crisis and collapse. You would *hope* that enough people would put the country over their party and prevent that...but maybe that's not how it would go in the modern US.

Comment: If there is a tie in the House Presidential Election but the Senate are able to elect a Vice President, then the Vice President-elect will become President upon vacancy of the Presidency.  If there is a tie in the Senate but the House elects a President, nothing happens. The President could appoint a Vice President after taking office according to usual 25th amendment provisions, but if congress again fails to approve, then the Vice Presidency will be vacant. This vacancy has existed on several occasions and would not present a crisis.   If there is a tie in both chambers, which is unlikely due to the Senate tiebreaker, but possible with abstention or absence, then that would present a greater challenge, presuming that all members hold firm in their votes. With a vacancy in the Presidency and the Vice Presidency, the Speaker will become President.

Comment: The 1800 election was under different rules though.  Originally, the person who got second place in the Electoral College would become Vice President.  But Electors got two votes for President.  The expectation would be that one vote would go to a local "favorite son" candidate, and the other would go to a more nationally-known candidate (hence the requirement that one vote be for a candidate from another state).  But in reality, national political parties formed early on, and spotted the strategic incentive to nominate *two* candidates for President (thus inventing "running mates"), so that Electors could vote for both, and the majority party would win *both* the Presidency and Vice Presidency.  (Obviously, this wouldn't have worked under a one-vote system, because it would split the vote and throw the election to the other party.)  In 1800, this plan worked *too* well, so that the two nominees from one party tied *each other*, and required the HoR to break the tie.  A hasty rule patch (12th Amendment) was made before the next election to distinguish between the Presidential and Vice Presidential votes.
